Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: IP blocked by globalcdn.nuget.org" (#9707) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

I'm unable to use NuGet.org

### Describe the bug

It seems that one of our public export IP `216.52.208.43` is blocked and cannot connect to `globalcdn.nuget.org` normally.
I tested other public export IPs and it was normal.

### Repro Steps

1. download package <https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/package/coverlet.msbuild/2.6.2>
2. cannot connect to globalcdn.nuget.org
3. finally get a 502 after 60s

### Expected Behavior

Hope it can be downloaded normally.

We are using JFrog Artifactory as an internal NuGet proxy and cache, and it has been working fine for the past few years.
I noticed that `globalcdn.nuget.org` was only started to be used recently. Are there some configurations that need to be optimized?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Advisories removed from GitHub still appear on NuGet.org" (#9706) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

At least one security advisory link on NuGet.org is broken. When you click it, GitHub shows a 404.

https://www.nuget.org/packages/bootstrap/4.2.1
links to
https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-fxwm-579q-49qq

```kusto
let advisory = "GHSA-fxwm-579q-49qq";
NiCatalogLeafItems
| where Vulnerabilities contains advisory
| summarize min(CommitTimestamp)
```

|min_CommitTimestamp|
|---|
|2020-07-17 07:21:57.4073455|

We first saw this advisory in July of 2020. It's not clear at what time the page began showing 404. Wayback Machine has no index for this.

We don't know if this is a GitHub data bug or something else.























### Repro Steps

https://www.nuget.org/packages/bootstrap/4.2.1
links to
https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-fxwm-579q-49qq

This GitHub URL is 404.

### Expected Behavior

The link should not be there if the advisory is withdrawn or the link should work.

The VerifyGitHubVulnerabilities job should report this as an error since we have an advisory in our DB that doesn't exist on GitHub (anymore?).

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Directory.Packages.props file not updated when adding a nuget dependency in a non-Sdk style project" (#12940) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

Visual Studio 17.7.5

### Worked before?

Can't say for sure

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

- In VS 2022, create a new "Console App (.NET Framework)" projet targeting .NET 4.7.2
- The project looks like this:
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Project ToolsVersion="15.0" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/developer/msbuild/2003">
  <Import Project="$(MSBuildExtensionsPath)\$(MSBuildToolsVersion)\Microsoft.Common.props" Condition="Exists('$(MSBuildExtensionsPath)\$(MSBuildToolsVersion)\Microsoft.Common.props')" />
  <PropertyGroup>
    <Configuration Condition=" '$(Configuration)' == '' ">Debug</Configuration>
    <Platform Condition=" '$(Platform)' == '' ">AnyCPU</Platform>
    ...
</Project>
```
- Create a file named "Directory.Packages.props" at the root of the project:
```xml
<Project>
  <PropertyGroup>
    <ManagePackageVersionsCentrally>true</ManagePackageVersionsCentrally>
  </PropertyGroup>
</Project>
```
- Right-click projet "Manage NuGet Packages..."
- Go to the Browse tab, select "Newtonsoft.Json" and install the package

The "Directory.Packages.props" file is not updated at all
Instead of updating the "Directory.Packages.props" file with the package+version, this is the csproj that gets updated with the version:
```xml
<ItemGroup>
  <PackageReference Include="Newtonsoft.Json">
    <Version>13.0.3</Version>
  </PackageReference>
</ItemGroup>
```
There is no particular message in the Package Manager console output.
If I create another project in the solution, a Sdk style project (NET6 for example), it works fine:
```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>net6.0</TargetFramework>
    ...
</Project>
```

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NullReferenceException in restore when a project with a misconfigured target framework" (#12939) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Take a project like for example: 

```csproj
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFrameworks>net6.0;net7.0;net.8.0</TargetFrameworks>
    <ImplicitUsings>enable</ImplicitUsings>
    <Nullable>enable</Nullable>
  </PropertyGroup>

</Project>
```

Observe an NRE in the output window. 

Now, this is fairly benign for the NuGet operation, but it also means that the EndSolutionRestoreJob event might not get fired https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/visual-studio-extensibility/nuget-api-in-visual-studio#ivsnugetprojectupdateevents-interface, and could potentially lead to issues/blocks on the CPS end.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Ability to pull a NuGet package and all of its dependencies into a single directory using the command-line" (#12938) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

NuGet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

Nuget does a great job of pulling down packages and all their dependencies.  But the form it brings them down leaves actually putting them together into a usable directory as an out-of-scope problem.  If you're working on C# source-code, this is fine.  But if you're trying to handle an .exe that lives in a nuget package, or if you're trying to access a nuget package in Powershell or CSX script, you can't actually load it because its dependencies are outside of the module search path.

So, proposal, call it "deploy".  As in 

```
nuget deploy mypackagename -OutputDirectory ./packages -DeployDirectory ./bin -Framework netcore
./bin/myPackageName.ExeTool.exe -someParam Foo
```

This is a pretty straightforward use of Nuget.exe, and yet the amount of code it requires is very very non-trivial.  See the Tolstoy at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39257572/loading-assemblies-from-nuget-packages

### Additional Context and Details

Detailed example.

Currently, if I do this:

```ps
nuget install Microsoft.Data.Tools.Msbuild -o ./packages
```

I get MsBuild and all its dependencies in `./packages`.  Which is great!  But if I try to use the copy of `SqlPackage.exe` that lives in there, I get the following:

```
> .\packages\Microsoft.Data.Tools.Msbuild.16.0.62004.28040\lib\net46\SqlPackage.exe

Unhandled Exception: System.IO.FileNotFoundException: Could not load file or assembly 'Microsoft.Data.Tools.Utilities, Version=15.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b03f5f7f11d50a3a' or one of its dependencies. The system cannot find the file specified.
   at Microsoft.Data.Tools.Schema.CommandLineTool.Program.Main(String[] args)
```

which is sad.  I have the file, I have the dependencies, it's just I have to put them together myself.

```
mkdir bin -Force
cp packages/*/lib/net46/* bin -Force

```

and then try it:

```
> .\bin\SqlPackage.exe | select-object -First 3 # we don't want the whole help doc
SqlPackage: Command-line tool for creating and deploying SQL Server databases and DACPAC packages.
Copyright (c) 2016 Microsoft Corporation.  All rights reserved.

```

So it works if you're willing to deploy the files out of the packages folder yourself.  Nuget being able to help with this would be fantastic.

dotnet.exe offers a similar service in `dotnet tool install` but it only allows things that are flagged as *tools*, and is very netcore oriented and so doesn't really work well with old framework things like nuget.exe does.

```
> dotnet tool install Microsoft.Data.Tools.Msbuild --tool-path ./bin

C:\Users\zaratem\AppData\Local\Temp\fc86e76c-4d47-498e-8a10-e120aaaa7ea3\restore.csproj : error NU1212: Invalid project-package combination for Microsoft.Data.Tools.Msbuild 16.0.62004.28040. DotnetToolReference project style
 can only contain references of the DotnetTool type
The tool package could not be restored.
Tool 'microsoft.data.tools.msbuild' failed to install. This failure may have been caused by:

* You are attempting to install a preview release and did not use the --version option to specify the version.
* A package by this name was found, but it was not a .NET tool.
* The required NuGet feed cannot be accessed, perhaps because of an Internet connection problem.
* You mistyped the name of the tool.

For more reasons, including package naming enforcement, visit https://aka.ms/failure-installing-tool
```

but for anything else, `dotnet tool install` does what we'd expect - it dumps the files I want to play with in the `bin` folder with all their dependencies where it needs them for when it's loaded into memory.

```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue ""error: Sequence contains no matching element" when listing outdated packages" (#12256) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

7.0.100, 6.0.300, 5.0.408, 3.1.425 (all I tested)

### Worked before?

no

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

1. `dotnet new console -o repro`
2. `dotnet add repro package AngleSharp --version 1.0.0-alpha-844` (note: this version was unlisted, the highest still-published version is 0.17.1)
3. (optional) `dotnet add repro package AngleSharp.Css --version 0.16.0` (note: highest released version is 0.16.4)
4. `dotnet list repro package --outdated --highest-minor` (or `--highest-patch`; the equivalent `dotnet nuget` command also fails)

What I expected:

I would expect the command to complete successfully. At a minimum it should still list the other package that's outdated (AngleSharp.Css 0.16.0 -> 0.16.4) if step 3 was run. It would also be nice to have a warning [like the one on nuget.org](https://www.nuget.org/packages/AngleSharp/1.0.0-alpha-844) about the AngleSharp version being unlisted, with a mention of the highest published version.

What I got:

```
The following sources were used:
   https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json

error: Sequence contains no matching element


Usage: NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat.dll package list [arguments] [options]
[...]
```

---

This made it more difficult to identify packages that needed I to update (note that `dotnet list repro package --outdated` also does not list AngleSharp) on a project with several dependencies. I hope it can be fixed to save others the same difficulty. Thanks for considering this issue.

Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

dotnet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

Add a dotnet nuget config command to manage NuGet configuration settings.

Tracking issues:
- [x] Spec: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/12297
- [x] Implement dotnet nuget config path(seasons of giving): https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8420

- [ ] Implement dotnet nuget config get
- [ ] Implement dotnet nuget config set/unset

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as March 15th, 2021" (#53) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The current NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as March 15th, 2021. If you validate that packages are repository signed by NuGet.org using a [NuGet client policy](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/consume-packages/installing-signed-packages), the [`NuGet.exe verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/reference/cli-reference/cli-ref-verify) command, or the [`dotnet nuget verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/tools/dotnet-nuget-verify) command, you will need to take steps by March 15th, 2021 to avoid disruptions when installing packages from NuGet.org that are signed with the new certificate. 

If you are unsure if you will be impacted or want to see instructions to allow the new certificate, please see our blogpost on the matter: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/the-nuget-org-repository-signing-certificate-will-be-updated-as-soon-as-march-15th-2021/

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The Microsoft author-signing certificate will be updated as soon as August 14th, 2023" (#70) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The current Microsoft author-signing certificate will be updated as soon as August 14th, 2023.  If you validate that packages are author signed by Microsoft using a [NuGet client policy](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/installing-signed-packages) or the [`verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/cli-reference/cli-ref-verify) command, you will need to take steps to avoid disruptions when installing Microsoft packages signed with the new certificate.

If you are unsure if you will be impacted or want to see instructions to allow the new certificate, please see our blog post on the matter: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/microsoft-author-signing-certificate-update-2023/
